nodes.bodyText: I think "releaseTrigger" should also be removed from the other workflows.

No "releaseTrigger" anymore, so I guess this is useless now since there will be no other build(s) to wait for? At least if I get this right … anyhow, I think this is fine. master has already been built and should be fine.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -2,18 +2,14 @@
 name: Release
 
 on:
-  create:
-    tags:
-      - 'releaseTrigger'
+  workflow_dispatch:
 
 jobs:
   deploy:
     runs-on: ubuntu-latest
     name: releasing
     steps:
       - uses: actions/checkout@v2
-        with:
-          ref: master
       - name: Wait on builds

nodes.bodyText: @aepfli sorry if I was imprecise, what I actually wanted to ask: shall we remove this step since there is no other build to wait for? What's your say on that?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -2,18 +2,14 @@
 name: Release

+  workflow_dispatch:

     steps:
       - uses: actions/checkout@v2
-        with:
-          ref: master
       - name: Wait on builds

nodes.bodyText: i would leave it actually, because theoretically, somebody could hit release on master branch, although all the checks are not finished.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -2,18 +2,14 @@

+  workflow_dispatch:

-          ref: master
       - name: Wait on builds

@@ -299,7 +299,7 @@ JUnit Pioneer uses [Shipkit](http://shipkit.org/) and [GitHub Actions](https://g
 Instead, releases must be triggered manually:
 
 1. make sure that the file [`version-properties`](version.properties) defines the correct version (see next section)
-2. push a tag `releaseTrigger` to `master`
+2. trigger the [`Release` GitHub Action](https://github.com/junit-pioneer/junit-pioneer/actions?query=workflow%3ARelease) manually for the master branch.
 
 GitHub Actions will then tell Shipkit to do its thing and afterwards delete the tag.
 The tag is always deleted, even if the release fails, so it is easy to trigger another one.
